text: Every now and then I come across code like this:

code:
foo = Foo()
...
if foo.bar is not None and foo.bar.baz == 42:
   shiny_happy(...)

text: Which seems, well, unpythonic, to me.
In Objective-C, you can send messages to nil and get nil as the answer.
I've always thought that's quite handy.
Of course it is possible to implement a Null pattern in Python, however judging from the results Google's given me, it seems this is not very widely used.
Or even better—would it be a bad idea to let None.whatever return None instead of raising an exception?
